I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the Country Programming Mission in April 2003, the Kingdom of Bhutan (the 
Government) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide an additional technical 
assistance (TA) grant to strengthen the capacity of Department of Aid and Debt Management 
(DADM), following TA 3893: Strengthening the Debt Management Capacity of the Department 
of Aid and Debt Management.1  The request was congruent with the Government’s efforts to 
develop its private sector. The TA was included in ADB's Country Strategy and Program Update 
2004–2006 for Bhutan.2 
 
2.  The Fact-Finding Mission (the Mission) visited Bhutan on 1–10 March 2004, and met 
with senior officials and technical staff from the Ministry of Finance (MOF), DADM, and Royal 
Monetary Authority (RMA). The Government and the Mission reached an understanding on the 
objectives, scope, financing plan, and implementation details of the TA. The TA framework is 
provided in Appendix 1. 
 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  One of the main objectives of the Government’s Ninth Plan (2002–2007) was identified 
as good governance. To attain this goal, the Government streamlined resource management in 
the public sector and monitored sovereign debt. However, given the scale of the task at hand, 
additional assistance was needed to support the reform agenda. The Government requested TA 
from ADB during the Country Programming Mission in April 2002, for the express purpose of 
strengthening Bhutan’s debt management capacity. ADB responded with advisory TA 3893, 
which was approved on 4 July 2002, and was implemented in the first quarter of 2003. Two TA 
consultants were engaged to develop the capacity of DADM staff to maintain a complete 
database of external debt and to accurately assess systemic and exogenous risks associated 
with the current debt portfolio of Bhutan.  
 
4.  Under the TA, the following were carefully reviewed: (i) the institutional framework for 
public sector borrowing; (ii) the management information system required for debt management; 
(iii)  the  legislative  and  regulatory  framework  for  borrowing,  on-lending,  and  government 
guarantees; (iv) debt and risk analysis; (v) borrowing policy and strategy; (vi) staffing and 
training requirements; and (vii) the need for a more structured public debt management in 
Bhutan.  Recommendations  on  regulatory,  institutional,  and  operational  aspects  of  debt 
management were made. The External Resources Management System (ERMS), the database 
used by DADM to monitor debt portfolio, was modified to follow the International Monetary Fund 
(IMF) format. The database is generated and managed using Excel and Access software 
programs, and classifies assistance by funding source, and by public and private sector (for 
government guarantee on on-lending to private sector). 
 
5.  The TA provided on-the-job training to DADM staff in debt management, risk analysis, 
and pertinent borrowing policy and strategies. In addition, staff from MOF’s Department of 
Budget and Accounts and from RMA were familiarized with fundamental debt management 
policy and issues.  Supported by the TA, five representatives from DADM and RMA went to the 
Philippines and studied the debt management system used by Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, the

Central  Bank  of  the  Philippines,  with  a  view  to  translating  this  knowledge  into  proficient 
sovereign debt management in Bhutan. 
    
6.  Following  completion  of  TA  3893,  a  number  of  issues  must  be  addressed  before 
DADM’s debt management capacity is fully developed. In particular, public debt management 
should be able to address the financing needs of the government, minimize borrowing costs, 
keep risks associated with borrowing at an acceptable minimum, and provide feedback to 
policy-makers for effective economic planning.  
 
7.  In creating such a debt management system, first a debt policy must be developed for 
Bhutan. The policy should formulate prudent management of the debt portfolio, and should 
dovetail seamlessly with Bhutan’s public expenditure management and economic development 
plan. Second, a loan procedures and regulations manual should be developed as a framework 
for the daily operations of DADM and other government institutions that work on external debt 
related topics. This framework should include operations issues pertaining to borrowing, debt 
management, and sustainability of debt.  
 
8.  Third,  necessary  hardware  and  software  should  be  available  to  support  a  more 
sophisticated  debt  monitoring  and  management  system.  Under  TA  3893,  the  ERMS  was 
redesigned to record and manage loans and grants. DADM uses two servers: one is assigned 
to daily use while the other acts as back-up. However, the ERMS is still embryonic and 
incomplete. Before descriptive reporting can be graduated into a more analytical approach to 
debt and aid management, all pertinent information must be promptly and accurately recorded 
on each loan, in accordance with established manuals and instructions. And debt management 
software packages should  be reviewed, with a view to graduating to a more sophisticated 
recording, monitoring, and management structure for sovereign debt. Software and computers 
to support such a system needs to be identified, procured, and made operational.  
 
9.  Finally, debt management is not merely database maintenance. It incorporates issues 
such as optimal levels of borrowing, servicing of outstanding debt, risk analysis, on-lending, 
recovery,  accounting,  and  budget  preparation.  And  the  capacity  to  perform  debt  and  risk 
analysis  can  only  be  built  over  time,  as  it  requires  expertise  in  portfolio  analysis,  risk 
management  techniques,  financial  management,  and  macroeconomics.  TA  3893  started 
capacity  building  at  the  micro  level,  by  familiarizing  DADM  staff  with  the  basics  of  debt 
management and risk analysis, using relatively simple data processing. To ensure sustainability, 
it is vital to develop and adopt a macro approach to debt management. Hence, in-house and 
external training should continue to develop staff capacity for analyzing debt-related data and 
managing risk from endogenous or exogenous shocks. DADM staff should be able to analyze 
the actual and predicted exposures to external risks, which in turn would facilitate informed 
management of the debt portfolio.  DADM should also be able to generate analytical status 
reports periodically so that information gleaned from debt management can feed into policy 
decisions.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
10.  The ultimate goal is to develop a comprehensive, forward-looking debt strategy, with a 
long-term macroeconomic sustainability focus in Bhutan. This TA will build on the findings and 
outputs of TA 3893, and support further development of the debt management capacity of 
DADM. More specifically, the TA will support the following tasks: (i) developing a debt policy to

3
 
record  and  manage  current  debt  as  well  as  to  guide  future  borrowing  decisions  of  the 
Government;  (ii)  preparing  a  loan  procedures  and  regulations  manual;  (iii)  designing  and 
operationalizing  a  complete  and  consolidated  database  on  all  loans  and  grants;  and  (iv) 
providing in-house and external training for staff in the proficient use of a computerized debt 
management system, sound management of the existing debt portfolio, comprehensive risk 
analysis, and a prescriptive analysis of the scope for a new borrowing position vis-à-vis the 
country's repayment capacity and development strategy.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  This TA will support the following activities. (i) A debt  policy, in accord with the 
strategic  development  plan  of  the  economy,  will  be  drafted.  (ii)  A  loan  procedures  and 
regulations manual will be developed. (iii) Equipment and software necessary for efficient debt 
management will be provided to DADM, of MOF. (iv) Provision of equipment and software will 
be supported through training given to staff of DADM, RMA, and other government offices 
working on debt-management-related activities. This training will include means of interfacing 
between the existing and new systems, fully using all features of the new software to prepare 
descriptive and prescriptive reports for internal and external use, as well as basic trouble-
shooting to maintain the newly-created debt management database during daily operations. (v) 
External training on international borrowing and debt management will be provided to a staff 
member from DADM’s Loans Division.3   
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $270,000 equivalent, comprising $220,000 in 
foreign exchange and $50,000 equivalent in local currency costs.  ADB will finance $225,000 
equivalent, which includes the entire foreign currency costs and $5,000 in local currency costs. 
The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB's TA funding program. The Government will 
contribute the remaining $45,000 equivalent in kind as office space and facilities, counterpart 
staff, local transportation, and administrative and clerical support. ADB's financing will be used 
for (i) acquiring the services of an international consultant, (ii) organizing workshops and 
providing training as required to counterpart staff, and (iii) acquiring the equipment and software 
necessary to implement the new debt management system. The detailed cost estimates and 
financing plan are provided in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
13.  DADM, MOF, will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The Director of DADM will 
oversee TA implementation. The TA will be implemented during a 9-month period starting in 
November 2004 and ending by August 2005. Two counterpart staff people will be nominated 
from DADM, and will work closely with the TA consultants to facilitate timely and effective TA 
implementation.  
 
14.  ADB  will  engage  two  individual  international  consultants,  in  accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants to provide the required consulting services, for a total of 6 
person-months (3 each). Consultancy services will be delivered intermittently. The consultants 
will be engaged through direct selection to ensure expeditious provision of consultancy services 
to  DADM  for  debt  management.  The  consultants  identified  for  the  consultancy  have  had 
experience working on debt management with DADM or other counterpart organizations in the

South Asia region; thus they  possess the specific type of expertise required for satisfactory 
implementation of this TA. The consultant team will comprise a public debt management 
specialist  and  a  debt  management  systems  specialist.  The  consultants  will  review  the 
recommendations of TA 3893 on the medium- and long-term needs of DADM in managing debt, 
and translate them into a debt management strategy and a debt policy for Bhutan. The TA 
consultants will also assist in institutional capacity building of DADM in identification, design, 
and/or procurement of computer programs necessary for recording, monitoring, and managing 
debt, as well as computer hardware and other office equipment to support the new debt 
management system. The outline terms of reference are provided in Appendix 3.  
 
15.  The consultants will prepare (i) an inception report, within 15 days of their fielding, 
including a needs-based assessment and an action plan; (ii) a midterm report, 1.5 months after 
fielding; (iii) a draft final report for the TA, to be submitted 2 weeks before the end of the 
consulting term; and (iv) a final report, at the end of the consulting assignment. All reports will 
be submitted (in hard and soft copies) to both DADM and ADB for review and comments. 
Consultants will duly incorporate the comments received from DADM and ADB while finalizing 
the reports. The findings and recommendations of the inception report and the draft final report 
will be discussed during tripartite meetings. 
 
16.  Additional computer software and hardware will  be needed to implement the new 
system. The consultants will identify the software and hardware that will support the new 
clearing  system.  Equipment  and  computer  hardware  and  software  will  be  procured  in 
accordance  with  ADB's  Guidelines  for  Procurement.  After  the  completion  of  the  TA,  all 
equipment purchased under the TA will be turned over to the Government. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $225,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for Strengthening the Debt Management Capacity of the Department 
of Aid and Debt Management, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will provide for 6 person-months of consulting services, 
carried out by two individual international consultants. The Consultants will have had sufficient 
prior experience in formulating and implementing debt policy, strategy, and management in a 
small economy context. They will undertake all tasks outlined in the terms of reference, as well 
as any other related tasks that may be required to achieve the objectives of the TA.  
 
A.  Public Debt Management Specialist and Team Leader (3 person-months) 
 
2.  The public debt management (PDM) specialist will be an economist with high-level 
academic qualifications and significant experience in managing public debt in small, developing 
economies, preferably those comparable to Bhutan, and conducting training. He or she will have 
had experience assessing the fiscal implications of external borrowing, national development 
planning, implementation of projects funded by external sources, public finance, and basic 
accounting. The specialist’s tasks under this TA will include the following:  
 
(i)  Review  and  assess  the  objectives  of  Bhutan’s  domestic  and  external  debt 
management, current institutional framework, and PDM practices. 
 
(ii)  In close consultation with Department of Aid and Debt Management (DADM) and 
Loan and Debt Division staff, draft a debt policy, in accord with the strategic 
development plan of the economy. The debt policy will suitably take into account 
the nature and exposure of Bhutan's debt dynamics relating to convertible and 
nonconvertible currency debt. 
 
(iii)  Prepare a loan procedures and regulations manual. 
 
(iv)  In close consultation with the Budget and Provision Office of the Ministry of 
Finance  (MOF)  and  the  Policy  and  Planning  Committee,  reviewing  debt 
coordination  and  public  debt  management  practices,  and  provide 
recommendations for improvement. 
 
(v)  In  collaboration  with  the  debt  management  software  specialist,  assess  the 
management  information  system  in  place  and  make  recommendations  for 
upgrading the current system. Then carry out the recommendations approved by 
the Director of DADM. 
 
(vi)  Assist  the  debt  management  software  specialist  and  DADM  staff  during 
identification,  procurement,  and  operationalization  of  hardware  and  software 
necessary to support the new debt management system. 
 
(vii)  Supervise the installation of the debt management software and data migration. 
Assist the debt management software specialist during the training of the users 
of this software. 
 
(viii)  With the debt management software specialist, prepare a long-term strategic 
development framework for identifying, acquiring, and implementing the PDM 
software package best suited for Bhutan.

debt  management.  Training  should  include  financial  and  debt  sustainability 
analyses based on the data generated by the PDM software. 
 
(x)  In  collaboration  with  the  debt  management  software  specialist  and  DADM, 
organize and conduct training seminars/workshops on PDM, for staff working on 
debt  management  in  MOF,  Royal  Monetary  Authority,  and  other  relevant 
government  agencies.  Training  will  ensure  that  PDM  staff  are  proficient  in 
maintaining the database, debt analyses, financial simulation, and forecasting

(xi)  Prepare a manual for training additional PDM staff in the future. 
 
(xii)  Prepare the inception, needs-based assessment and action plan, and midterm, 
draft final and final TA reports, based on the findings from (i)-(x), inputs from the 
debt management software specialist, and feedback from DADM and Asian 
Development Bank. 
 
 
B.  Debt Management Software Specialist (3 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant will be a PDM specialist, who has had at least 5 years of experience with 
major debt management software packages (e.g. CS-DRMS of Commonwealth Secretariat, 
DMFAS of UNCTAD, DSM+ of World Bank, private packages such as Debt-Pro). The consultant 
will work closely with DADM staff, especially during the installation and implementation of the 
PDM software package. The specialist’s responsibilities will include the following: 
 
(i)  In collaboration with the PDM specialist and DADM, identify a debt management 
software program. Oversee procurement and installation of any hardware or 
software necessary to support the new debt management system. 
 
(ii)  Set up the system, procedures, documentation for server and database backup 
and recovery. 
 
(iii)  Oversee the loan database migration to the new debt management system, and 
ensure data validation. 
 
(iv)  Incorporate linkages with aid management in the PDM software program. 
 
(v)  Devise necessary forms and incorporate form management into the existing 
program. 
 
(vi)  Incorporate forecasting capabilities into the existing spreadsheet-based system 
to enable debt service forecasts to be generated. 
 
(vii)  Update the current debt management system to address loans, grants, and 
government guarantees. 
 
(viii)  Review data capture arrangements in the system to ensure all transaction data 
are captured accurately.
